evidence: These coils send radio waves to disturb the alignment of the protons in the body. When the protons are tipped away from alignment, they begin to precess, and in doing so, they emit their own radiofrequency signals.

triples.evidence: The instrumentation involved in MRI consists of a superconducting magnet, three sets of magnetic field gradients (only one is shown), and a radiofrequency coil.

concepts.term: turn these detected signals into detailed images

evidence: Around it, we place gradient coils, which allow us to vary the magnetic field in different directions and make tomographic, or slice-by-slice, imaging possible.

triples.evidence: At the center of the system, we have a large superconducting magnet. This magnet creates a very strong, stable magnetic field.
